title: 106_hr2177
content: The Act may be cited as the "James Peak Wilderness Act of 1999" and designates the James Peak Wilderness in Colorado. The James Peak Wilderness Act of 1999 amends the Colorado Wilderness Act of 1993 to include certain lands in the Arapaho National Forest as the James Peak Wilderness, comprising approximately 22,000 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to file a map and boundary description of the wilderness area with the relevant committees in Congress. The Colorado Wilderness Act of 1993 allows the Secretary to correct errors in the map and boundary descriptions. The documents are available for public inspection at the Office of the Chief of the Forest Service. SEC. 3. INHOLDINGS IN JAMES PEAK WILDERNESS. The Secretary of Agriculture will negotiate with the Colorado State Land Board for the transfer of lands within the James Peak Wilderness. Additionally, negotiations will take place with the owner of lands in the Jim Creek drainage for potential acquisition by purchase or exchange. Upon reaching an agreement for acquisition, a report will be issued within one year of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a report to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act regarding agreements or negotiations for land acquisition. The report will detail the availability of funds for land acquisition and whether additional funds are needed. SEC. 4. ALICE TOWNSHIP AND ST. MARY'S GLACIER, COLORADO. The Forest Supervisor of the Arapaho and Roosevelt National Forests in Colorado will establish facilities and services at Alice Township and St. Mary's Glacier, including trailhead parking, restrooms, and maintenance. Forest Service personnel will manage the area, following consultation with Clear Creek County Commissioners and residents. The Forest Supervisor will consult with Clear Creek County Commissioners and residents regarding the location of facilities and services at Alice Township and St. Mary's Glacier. A report will be submitted to relevant committees on the additional funding needed for implementation. SEC. 5. POTENTIAL WILDERNESS LANDS. The term "potential wilderness lands" refers to areas designated as potential wilderness on a specific map. These lands will be managed as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System once all structures are removed and incompatible uses have ceased. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to remove an abandoned radio tower on Mount Eva within these potential wilderness lands.
